trans-unit.source: Certificates Overview for Azure Cloud Services
trans-unit.target: Certificates Overview for Azure Cloud Services

trans-unit.source: Certificates are used in Azure for cloud services ([service certificates](#what-are-service-certificates)) and for authenticating with the management API ([management certificates](#what-are-management-certificates)).
trans-unit.target: Certificates are used in Azure for cloud services ([service certificates](#what-are-service-certificates)) and for authenticating with the management API ([management certificates](#what-are-management-certificates)).

trans-unit.source: This topic gives a general overview of both certificate types, how to [create](#create) them, and how to [deploy](#deploy) them to Azure.
trans-unit.target: This topic gives a general overview of both certificate types, how to [create](#create) them, and how to [deploy](#deploy) them to Azure.

trans-unit.source: Certificates used in Azure are x.509 v3 certificates and can be signed by another trusted certificate or they can be self-signed.
trans-unit.target: Certificates used in Azure are x.509 v3 certificates and can be signed by another trusted certificate or they can be self-signed.

trans-unit.source: A self-signed certificate is signed by its own creator, and because of this, are not trusted by default.
trans-unit.target: A self-signed certificate is signed by its own creator, and because of this, are not trusted by default.

trans-unit.source: Most browsers can ignore this.
trans-unit.target: Most browsers can ignore this.

trans-unit.source: Self-signed certificates should only be used by yourself when developing and testing your cloud services.
trans-unit.target: Self-signed certificates should only be used by yourself when developing and testing your cloud services.

trans-unit.source: Certificates used by Azure can contain a private or a public key.
trans-unit.target: Certificates used by Azure can contain a private or a public key.

trans-unit.source: Certificates have a thumbprint that provides a means to identify them in an unambiguous way.
trans-unit.target: Certificates have a thumbprint that provides a means to identify them in an unambiguous way.

trans-unit.source: This thumbprint is used in the Azure [configuration file](cloud-services-configure-ssl-certificate.md) to identify which certificate a cloud service should use.
trans-unit.target: This thumbprint is used in the Azure [configuration file](cloud-services-configure-ssl-certificate.md) to identify which certificate a cloud service should use.

trans-unit.source: What are service certificates?
trans-unit.target: What are service certificates?

trans-unit.source: Service certificates are attached to cloud services and enable secure communication to and from the service.
trans-unit.target: Service certificates are attached to cloud services and enable secure communication to and from the service.

trans-unit.source: For example, if you deployed a web role, you would want to supply a certificate that can authenticate an exposed HTTPS endpoint.
trans-unit.target: For example, if you deployed a web role, you would want to supply a certificate that can authenticate an exposed HTTPS endpoint.

trans-unit.source: Service certificates, defined in your service definition, are automatically deployed to the virtual machine that is running an instance of your role.
trans-unit.target: Service certificates, defined in your service definition, are automatically deployed to the virtual machine that is running an instance of your role.

trans-unit.source: You can upload service certificates to Management Portal either using the Management Portal or by using the Service Management API.
trans-unit.target: You can upload service certificates to Management Portal either using the Management Portal or by using the Service Management API.

trans-unit.source: Service certificates are associated with a specific cloud service and assigned to a deployment in the service definition file.
trans-unit.target: Service certificates are associated with a specific cloud service and assigned to a deployment in the service definition file.

trans-unit.source: Service certificates can be managed separately from your services, and may be managed by different individuals.
trans-unit.target: Service certificates can be managed separately from your services, and may be managed by different individuals.

trans-unit.source: For example, a developer may upload a service package that refers to a certificate that an IT manager has previously uploaded to Azure.
trans-unit.target: For example, a developer may upload a service package that refers to a certificate that an IT manager has previously uploaded to Azure.

trans-unit.source: An IT manager can manage and renew that certificate changing the configuration of the service without needing to upload a new service package.
trans-unit.target: An IT manager can manage and renew that certificate changing the configuration of the service without needing to upload a new service package.

trans-unit.source: This is possible because the logical name for the certificate and its store name and location are specified in the service definition file, while the certificate thumbprint is specified in the service configuration file.
trans-unit.target: This is possible because the logical name for the certificate and its store name and location are specified in the service definition file, while the certificate thumbprint is specified in the service configuration file.

trans-unit.source: To update the certificate, it's only necessary to upload a new certificate and change the thumbprint value in the service configuration file.
trans-unit.target: To update the certificate, it's only necessary to upload a new certificate and change the thumbprint value in the service configuration file.

trans-unit.source: What are management certificates?
trans-unit.target: What are management certificates?

trans-unit.source: Management certificates allow you to authenticate with the Service Management API provided by Azure.
trans-unit.target: Management certificates allow you to authenticate with the Service Management API provided by Azure.

trans-unit.source: Many programs and tools (such as Visual Studio or the Azure SDK) will use these certificates to automate configuration and deployment of various Azure services.
trans-unit.target: Many programs and tools (such as Visual Studio or the Azure SDK) will use these certificates to automate configuration and deployment of various Azure services.

trans-unit.source: These are not really related to cloud services.
trans-unit.target: These are not really related to cloud services.

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.WARNING] Be careful!
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.WARNING] Be careful!

trans-unit.source: These types of certificates allow anyone who authenticates with them to manage the subscription they are associated with.
trans-unit.target: These types of certificates allow anyone who authenticates with them to manage the subscription they are associated with.

trans-unit.source: Limitations
trans-unit.target: Limitations

trans-unit.source: There is a limit of 100 management certificates per subscription.
trans-unit.target: There is a limit of 100 management certificates per subscription.

trans-unit.source: There is also a limit of 100 management certificates for all subscriptions under a specific service administrator’s user ID.
trans-unit.target: There is also a limit of 100 management certificates for all subscriptions under a specific service administrator’s user ID.

trans-unit.source: If the user ID for the account administrator has already been used to add 100 management certificates and there is a need for more certificates, you can add a co-administrator to add the additional certificates.
trans-unit.target: If the user ID for the account administrator has already been used to add 100 management certificates and there is a need for more certificates, you can add a co-administrator to add the additional certificates.

trans-unit.source: Before adding more than 100 certificates, see if you can reuse an existing certificate.
trans-unit.target: Before adding more than 100 certificates, see if you can reuse an existing certificate.

trans-unit.source: Using co-administrators adds potentially unneeded complexity to your certificate management process.
trans-unit.target: Using co-administrators adds potentially unneeded complexity to your certificate management process.

trans-unit.source: Create a new self-signed certificate
trans-unit.target: Create a new self-signed certificate

trans-unit.source: You can use any tool available to create a self-signed certificate as long as they adhere to these settings:
trans-unit.target: You can use any tool available to create a self-signed certificate as long as they adhere to these settings:

trans-unit.source: An X.509 certificate.
trans-unit.target: An X.509 certificate.

trans-unit.source: Contains a private key.
trans-unit.target: Contains a private key.

trans-unit.source: Created for key exchange (.pfx file).
trans-unit.target: Created for key exchange (.pfx file).

trans-unit.source: Subject name must match the domain used to access the cloud service.
trans-unit.target: Subject name must match the domain used to access the cloud service.

trans-unit.source: You cannot acquire an SSL certificate for the cloudapp.net (or for any Azure related) domain; the certificate's subject name must match the custom domain name used to access your application.
trans-unit.target: You cannot acquire an SSL certificate for the cloudapp.net (or for any Azure related) domain; the certificate's subject name must match the custom domain name used to access your application.

trans-unit.source: For example, **contoso.net**, not **contoso.cloudapp.net**.
trans-unit.target: For example, **contoso.net**, not **contoso.cloudapp.net**.

trans-unit.source: Minimum of 2048-bit encryption.
trans-unit.target: Minimum of 2048-bit encryption.

trans-unit.source: **Service Certificate Only**: Client-side certificate must reside in the *Personal* certificate store.
trans-unit.target: **Service Certificate Only**: Client-side certificate must reside in the *Personal* certificate store.

trans-unit.source: There are two easy ways to create a certificate on Windows, with the `makecert.exe` utility, or IIS.
trans-unit.target: There are two easy ways to create a certificate on Windows, with the `makecert.exe` utility, or IIS.

trans-unit.source: Makecert.exe
trans-unit.target: Makecert.exe

trans-unit.source: This utility is installed with Visual Studio 2013/2015.
trans-unit.target: This utility is installed with Visual Studio 2013/2015.

trans-unit.source: It is a console utility that allows you to create and install certificates.
trans-unit.target: It is a console utility that allows you to create and install certificates.

trans-unit.source: If you launch the **Developer Command Prompt for VS2015** shortcut that is created when you install Visual Studio, a command prompt will appear that has this tool in path.
trans-unit.target: If you launch the **Developer Command Prompt for VS2015** shortcut that is created when you install Visual Studio, a command prompt will appear that has this tool in path.
